passage_text: I need help in deciding on Norway Spruce or White Spruce. I plan to plant two rows of evergreen trees to buffer the front yard from the semi busy road. Because of the deer issue, I seem to be left with spruce trees as the only options.hite Spruce comes cheaper by 1/3 than Norway Spruce, other than that, I don't know what's the difference between these two kinds of spruces and would appreciate any input in helping me making the choice.

conifer; coniferous tree (any gymnospermous tree or shrub bearing cones) Meronyms (substance of spruce): spruce (light soft moderately strong wood of spruce trees; used especially for timbers and millwork) Hyponyms (each of the following is a kind of spruce): Picea obovata; Siberian spruce (tall spruce of northern Europe and Asia; resembles Norway spruce)

Spruce Tree Scientific Name, Picea. Spruce trees are cone bearing trees and can therefore be classified as coniferous. Other coniferous trees include pine trees, Douglas Fir trees, redwood trees and cedar trees. Spruce Tree Types: List of Different Type of Spruce. Bird's Nest Spruce, dwarf variety of Norway Spruce.

Pine trees have needles in bundles of two, three, or five along the stem. Spruce trees are experiencing three different diseases, each with slightly different symptoms and treatment.

EVERGREEN TREE TYPES. In botany, an evergreen tree type or plant is a plant that has leaves in all seasons. This contrasts with deciduous tree type or plants, which completely lose their foliage during the winter or dry season. There are many different kinds of evergreen plants, both trees and shrubs. Evergreens include: most species of conifers (e.g., hemlock trees, blue spruce tree , red cedar, and white/scots/jack pine trees) live oak, holly, and ancient gymnosperms such as cycads.

The spruce trees of North America include seven different species, all of them growing north of Mexico, mostly in cool climate locations. Spruce trees are important producers of lumber and are also useful in an ornamental capacity.

Spruce trees are important producers of lumber and are also useful in an ornamental capacity. The spruces all have evergreen needles, most are tall and they have a conical shape.

Fir, spruce, and pine are three of the most popular Christmas tree varieties and have their own characteristics that make them special.

The gymnosperms are primarily conifers (cone bearing trees and shrubs) such as the spruce, pine and fir trees. They are non-flowering plants that produce seeds not encased in â¦any kind of carpel or fruit. The seeds form on the scales of the cone.

Differences Between Spruce & Fir Trees. Spruce and fir trees are biologically close cousins that belong to the family of evergreens known as conifers, or cone-bearing trees. Both species inhabit northern or high-altitude regions where the weather is typically cold during winter. At one time both species were referred to as fir trees.

One of the easiest ways to tell the difference between a spruce tree and a pine tree is by looking closely at their needles. While spruce needles tend to be shorter than those of pines -- roughly 1-inch long -- it's their notable stiffness that really gives them away.

There are several different tree species used as Christmas trees, such as the fir, pine, spruce, cypress and cedar. For each of the main category of Christmas trees, there are also different types among those. Plus, there are many different varieties of artificial Christmas trees available. Continue Reading.

Taiga: Plants Because the climate of the taiga is very cold, there is not a large variety of plant life. The most common type of tree found in the taiga is the conifer--trees that have cones.Four kinds of conifers are common in the taiga. Three of the common conifers are evergreens; spruce, fir, and pine.The fourth common conifer is the tamarack, or larch, a deciduous tree.Under certain conditions, broadleaf trees, such as birch and aspen, are able to survive the harsh climate of the taiga.our kinds of conifers are common in the taiga. Three of the common conifers are evergreens; spruce, fir, and pine. The fourth common conifer is the tamarack, or larch, a deciduous tree. Under certain conditions, broadleaf trees, such as birch and aspen, are able to survive the harsh climate of the taiga.
